cubemapTOP.label: cubemapTOP

members.text: Menu : Determine how the cube map is created from the input images.
members.name: mode

cubemapTOP.long:
The Cube Map TOP builds a texture map in the [[Cube Map]] internal texture format. It accepts a vertical cross image, or 1 input per side of the cube. The [[Phong MAT]] can use the cube maps from the Cube Map TOP for reflections. The [[Render TOP]] can also create cube maps. You can sample a cube map in a GLSL shader by declaring them like this		
<syntaxhighlight lang=glsl>uniform samplerCube <name>;</syntaxhighlight>			
and sampling them using this in GLSL 3.30+			
<syntaxhighlight lang=glsl>texture(samplerCube name, vec3 texcoords)</syntaxhighlight>			
			
or this in GLSL 1.20			
<syntaxhighlight lang=glsl>textureCube(samplerCube name, vec3 texcoords)</syntaxhighlight>
cubemapTOP.short: The Cube Map TOP builds a texture map in the [[Cube Map]] internal texture format.

depthTOP.label: depthTOP

members.text: OP : Specifies the Render TOP used for depth values.
members.name: rendertop

members.text: Int : When using [[Multi-Camera Rendering]], chooses which camera's output to select.
members.name: cameraindex

members.text: Int : When using the 'Depth-Peeling' feature in the [[Render TOP]], this chooses which peel layer to select.
members.name: peellayerindex

members.text: Menu : The pixel format the Depth texture should be output as.
members.name: pixelformat

members.text: Menu : The space the depth values should be output in.
members.name: depthspace

members.text: Float : The range to convert from when using 'Rerange from Camera Space'. This would often be your area of interest in the camera's depth.
members.name: rangefrom

members.text: Float : The range of values you want to convert the depth values to. This is the range you would find the depth to more useful for processing, often 0-1.
members.name: rangeto

members.text: Toggle : Enable to clamp the depth values between 0 and 1.
members.name: clamp

members.text: Float : Apply a  gamma curve to the depth values.
members.name: gamma

depthTOP.short: The Depth TOP reads an image containing depth information from a scene described in a specified [[Render TOP]]. The resulting image is black (0) at pixels where the surface is at the near depth value (Camera's parameter "Near"). It is white (1) at pixels where the surface is at the far depth value (parameter "Far").
depthTOP.long:
The Depth TOP reads an image containing depth information from a scene described in a specified [[Render TOP]]. The resulting image is black (0) at pixels where the surface is at the near depth value (Camera's parameter "Near"). It is white (1) at pixels where the surface is at the far depth value (parameter "Far"). 		
			
The Depth TOP is used to do shadow mapping. It can have many other uses also, such as edge detection based on depth. 			
			
The depth range is by definition the near plane -> far plane. Values in the Depth TOP will be 0 at the near plane, and 1 at the far plane. Generally the image in the Depth TOP will be white, unless you have your planes really tight around your object. But just because you can't visually see anything, it doesn't mean the information isn't there. 			
			
Another option is Linear Camera-Space Depth. If the Render TOP's Depth Buffer Format is set to 32-Bit Floating-Point and its Linear Camera-Space Depth parameter is on, then the Depth TOP will output linear camera space depth.			
			
You can use the [[Level TOP]] to re-range the Depth TOP's values. However make sure you set the Pixel Format of the Level TOP to 16 or 32-bit, or you'll lose a lot of information from the Depth TOP's data (The Depth TOP has 24-bit data).			
			
The Depth TOP creates a 24-bit fixed-point or 32-bit floating-point single channel image. When the Depth TOP is used as an input to another TOP, its data will be treated like an RGBA value of (D, D, D, 1). The same is true when sampling a depth texture in a GLSL shader.

differenceTOP.label: differenceTOP

members.text: Menu : The selected input will become the fixed layer and the other input will be the overlay. This does not change the order of the composite (Input1 + Input2), only which layer is considered fixed and which layer is adjustable by the parameters on the Transform page. The resolution and aspect ratio of the Fixed Layer is used as the composite's final resolution and aspect ratio unless manually on the [[#Parameters - Common Page|Common Page]]
members.name: size

members.text: Menu : Determines how the Overlay layer (Overlay layer is the input that is NOT the Fixed Layer) fills the composite.
members.name: prefit

members.text: Menu : Specify the horizontal alignment of the Overlay.
members.name: justifyh

members.text: Menu : Specify the vertical alignment of the Overlay.
members.name: justifyv

members.text: Menu : Sets the extend (or repeat) conditions of the Overlay layer. This parameter determines what happens at the edges of the Overlay layer.
members.name: extend

members.text: Float : Rotates the Overlay layer. Increasing values rotate clockwise, decreasing values rotate counter-clockwise.
members.name: r

members.text: XY : Translates the Overlay layer in x and y.
members.name: t

members.text: Menu : Sets the units used in the Translate parameter.
members.name: tunit

members.text: XY : Scales the Overlay layer in x and y.
members.name: s

members.text: XY : Allows you to define the point about which the Overlay layer scales and rotates. Altering the pivot point produces different results depending on the Transform Order.
members.name: p

members.text: Menu : Sets the units used in the Pivot parameter.
members.name: punit

differenceTOP.short: The Difference TOP performs a difference composite on its two input images.
differenceTOP.long: The Difference TOP performs a difference composite on its two input images.

directxinTOP.label: directxinTOP

members.text: Str : Specify the handle pointing to the DirectX texture. You can get the handle of any [[DirectX Out TOP]] texture by attaching an [[Info DAT]] to it. The handle is one of the columns. Other applications that support sharing texture will have their own way of getting a texture handle, please consult the application's documentation.
members.name: handle

directxinTOP.short: The DirectX In TOP brings DirectX textures from other applications into TouchDesigner.
directxinTOP.long:
The DirectX In TOP brings DirectX textures from other applications into TouchDesigner. This feature is accessed through the DirectX Sharing Resources feature. This supports DirectX 9.0 and higher.	
		
See also: [[DirectX Out TOP]]

directxoutTOP.label: directxoutTOP

members.text: Toggle : Enable or disable DirectX output.
members.name: active

members.text: Int : Number of DirectX textures created. These textures are updated in a cycle, 1 per frame. Use an [[Info DAT]] to inspect the list of textures.
members.name: queuesize

directxoutTOP.long:
The DirectX Out TOP creates textures that a DirectX application can access, or any instance of TouchDesigner with a DirectX In TOP. This features is accessed though the DirectX Sharing Resources feature. This supports DirectX 9.0 and higher.	
		
See also: [[DirectX In TOP]]
directxoutTOP.short: The DirectX Out TOP creates textures that a DirectX application can access, or any instance of TouchDesigner with a DirectX In TOP.

displaceTOP.label: displaceTOP

members.text: Menu : Instead of using the Red channel to displace horizontally, you can choose a different channel.
members.name: horzsource

members.text: Menu : Instead of using the Blue channel to displace vertically, you can choose a different channel.
members.name: vertsource

members.text: XY : This value is the color values that will result in no displacement. Values below this will cause the displacement to come from the left/bottom of the pixel, while values above this will cause the displacement to come from the right/top of the pixel.
members.name: midpoint

members.text: XY : This scales the offset caused by the Displace Image. It will cause the pixels fetched to be closer/farther along the sample vector created by the Horizontal and Vertical Source.
members.name: displaceweight

members.text: Float : This reduces the influence of the pixel's position when brought toward 0. At its default of 1, it doesn't zoom into the Displace Image. When 0, it anchors the displacements relative to one pixel in the Source Image defined by the Offset and Offset Weight parameters.
members.name: uvweight

members.text: XY : The Offset is first multiplied by the Offset Weight. Then it will be added to the coordinates caluclated after looking up into the displacement map. These final coordinates is what will be used to sample from the source image.
members.name: offset

members.text: Float : Scales the Offset parameter values. When this is 0 the Offset parameter will have no effect.
members.name: offsetweight

members.text: Menu : This parameter determines what happens at the edges of the tiles.
members.name: extend

displaceTOP.long:
The Displace TOP will cause one image to be warped by another image. A pixel of the output image at (Uo,Vo) gets its RGBA value from a different pixel (Ui, Vi) of the Source Image by using the second input image (the Displace Image). 		
			
For each pixel in the output image, three factors affect which pixel to fetch from the source:			
* The horizontal and vertical source channels of the Displace Image (Red and Blue by default).
* the Uo and Vo coordinate of the output pixel.			
* A constant Ua and Va anchor point (Offset).			
			
'''Displace Image''' - In using the Displace Image, for each pixel in the output, it gets the corresponding pixel from the input, and uses the red channel and blue channel as its U and V displacement. If the red and blue are .5, .5, then Uo = Ui and Vo = Vi. That is, there is no warp if the Displace Image is a 50% grey. Also the warp is reduced to 0 if the Displace Weight is 0. Where red < .5 in the Displace Image, it fetches a pixel from the left of Uo in the Source Image. If blue < .5, it fetches a pixel from below Vo in the Source Image. Thus the pixel is retrieved from Ui, Vi at Uo*Scale*(red-.5), Vo*Scale*(.5-blue) of the Source Image.			
			
'''Uo and Vo offset''' - By default, the warping of each output pixel is relative to its Uo, Vo. But when the UV Weight parameter is 0, the displacement is relative to the center pixel of the Source Image.			
			
'''Ua and Va anchor (offset) point''' - This zooms into a pixel of the input if you bring the two other weights down to 0.			
			
For the Displace Image, you can change which of its RGBA channels cause the warp. 			
			
You can choose if there is wraparound in the image warping. If the computed Uo and Vo is less than 0 or greater than 1, it can wraparound, clamp or mirror.			
			
The Displace Image can be any photograph followed by a Slope TOP, which will give luminance gradients in red and blue, with the neutral value at .5, exactly the form required by the Displace TOP.			
			
One way to experiment is to make a Displace Image from Ramp TOPs. Alternately use a Constant TOP set to .5, .5, .5, 1, then subtract a photo using a Subtract TOP, and add another photo image using an Add TOP. Before subtracting and adding the images, you can lower their effect using Level TOPs and adjusting Brightness.			
			
See also: [[Remap TOP]], [[Lookup TOP]]
displaceTOP.short: The Displace TOP will cause one image to be warped by another image.

edgeTOP.label: edgeTOP

members.text: Menu : This menu determines how the edges are pulled from the image.
members.name: select

members.text: Float : Applies a black level adjustment to the input image before finding the edges.
members.name: blacklevel

members.text: Float : Higher gain values will make more edge details appear.
members.name: strength

members.text: Float : When sampling the image, this determines the distance from each pixel to the sample pixel. When units are set to pixels, it is the number of pixels away from the current pixel which is sampled to find edges. A Sample Step of 3 would sample pixels 3 pixels away to look for edges.
members.name: offset

members.text: Menu :
members.name: offsetunit

members.text: RGBA : The color of the edges in RGBA.
members.name: edgecolor

members.text: Menu : This menu determines how the alpha channel is output from the Edge TOP.
members.name: alphaoutputmenu

members.text: Toggle : Turning this On will composite the edges over the input image.
members.name: compinput

edgeTOP.long:
The Edge TOP finds edges in an image and highlights them. For each pixel, it looks at the values at neighboring pixels, and where differences are greater than a threshold, the output's value is higher.		
			
See also the [[Convolve TOP]].
edgeTOP.short: The Edge TOP finds edges in an image and highlights them.

embossTOP.label: embossTOP

members.text: Menu : This menu selects how the edges in the image are found. The edges will appear raised or depressed in the output image depending on their slope.
members.name: select

members.text: Menu : Determines what pixels to use when calculating the slope at each pixel in the image.
members.name: method

members.text: Float : Sets the greyscale color of the midpoint of the emboss. This is the color of any part in the image that is not raised or depressed.
members.name: midpoint

members.text: Float : The depth of the emboss. Higher values make the output look more deeply etched.
members.name: strength

members.text: Float : When sampling the image, this determines the distance from each pixel to the sample pixel. When units are set to pixels, it is the number of pixels away from the current pixel which is sampled to find edges. A Sample Step of 3 would sample pixels 3 pixels away to look for edges.
members.name: offset

members.text: Menu :
members.name: offsetunit

members.text: Float : Controls the position of the light source, changing the direction of the highlights and shadows in the embossed output image.
members.name: direction

embossTOP.long: The Emboss TOP creates the effect that an image is embossed in a thin sheet of metal. Edges in the image will appear raised.
embossTOP.short: The Emboss TOP creates the effect that an image is embossed in a thin sheet of metal.

feedbackTOP.label: feedbackTOP

members.text: TOP : Specifies a TOP for feedback to use as its source when activated.
members.name: top

members.text: Toggle : Activates feedback when set to 0. Disables feedback when set to 1. When disabled, the Feedback TOP passes thru the image connected to its input.
members.name: reset

members.text: Pulse : Resets the feedback in a single frame when clicked.
members.name: resetpulse

feedbackTOP.long: The Feedback TOP can be used to create feedback effects in TOPs. It can give fake motion blur by not clearing the color buffer. The Feedback TOP's input image will be passed through whenever Feedback is bypassed (by setting the Bypass Feedback parameter = 1). When feedback is activated (Bypass Feedback parameter = 0) the Feedback TOP will output an image stream sourced from its Target TOP. By selecting a Target TOP downstream in the feedback network, other filter TOPs can be added in between the Feedback TOP and its Target TOP to achive feedback effects. See the example networks below. See [[OP Snippets]] for some examples on how to use the Feedback TOP.
feedbackTOP.short: The Feedback TOP can be used to create feedback effects in TOPs.

fitTOP.label: fitTOP

members.text: Menu : Determines how the input is fit to the specified resolution.
members.name: fit

members.text: Menu : The menu attached to this parameter allows you to specify the order in which the changes to your TOP will take place. Changing the Transform order will change where things go much the same way as going a block and turning east gets you to a different place than turning east and then going a block.
members.name: xord

members.text: XY : The two fields for Translate and Scale allows you to specify transforms in x and y axes. The field for Rotate allow you to specify the amount of rotation.
members.name: t

members.text: Menu : Sets the units used in the Translate parameter.
members.name: tunit

members.text: XYZ : The field for rotation allows you to specify the amount of rotation of the image.
members.name: r

members.text: XY : The two fields for Scale allows you to specify transforms in x and y axes.
members.name: s

members.text: XY : The Pivot point edit fields allow you to define the point about which the TOP scales and rotates. Altering the pivot point of a TOP produces different results depending on the transformation performed on the TOP image. For example, during a scaling operation, if the pivot point of a TOP image is located at -1,-1 and you wanted to scale the image by 0.5 (reduce its size by 50%), then the TOP would scale toward the pivot point and appear to slide down and to the left.
members.name: p

members.text: Menu : Sets the units used in the Pivot parameter.
members.name: punit

members.text: RGBA : Color applied behind the foreground image. The background is visible when the image is translated or scaled down. Try scaling an image down 50% in size (Scale = 0.5,0.5) and setting the background color.
members.name: bgcolor

members.text: Toggle : This option allows the Background Color to be pre-multiplied by alpha.
members.name: premultrgbbyalpha

fitTOP.long: The Fit TOP re-sizes its input to the resolution set on the Common Page using the method specified in the Fit parameter menu. This is useful for changing the aspect ratio of an image without distorting it horizontally or vertically. It will crop the image or fill with the background color depending on the Fit parameter options.
fitTOP.short: The Fit TOP re-sizes its input to the resolution set on the Common Page using the method specified in the Fit parameter menu.

flipTOP.label: flipTOP

members.text: Toggle : Flips the image in X.
members.name: flipx

members.text: Toggle : Flips the image in Y.
members.name: flipy

members.text:
Menu : Flops the image. Flop is a combination of a flip and a rotation. The X resolution becomes the Y resolution. The Y becomes the X.	
			
* No Flop - No flop performed.			
* Bottom Left - The image is flipped in X and then rotated 90 degrees clockwise.			
* Top Left - The image is flipped in X and then rotated 90 degrees counter-clockwise.
members.name: flop

flipTOP.long: The Flip TOP will Flip an image in X and/or Y. It also offers a Flop option to turn each row of pixels into a column.
flipTOP.short: The Flip TOP will Flip an image in X and/or Y.

functionTOP.label: functionTOP

members.text: Float : Applies a scale and shift to the input values before the function is calculated i.e. input = (input * rerange2) + rerange1. '''Note:''' This feature only affects integer texture formats and is not used on floating point formats.
members.name: rerange

members.text: Menu : Applies the selected function to the R, G, B, and A channels.
members.name: funcrgba

members.text: Menu : Applies the selected function to the R, G, and B channels.
members.name: funcrgb

members.text: Menu : Applies the selected function to the R (red) channel.
members.name: funcr

members.text: Menu : Applies the selected function to the G (green) channel.
members.name: funcg

members.text: Menu : Applies the selected function to the B (blue) channel.
members.name: funcb

members.text: Menu : Applies the selected function to the A (alpha) channel.
members.name: funca

members.text: Float : Supplies the base value for functions like 'Log Base N' and 'Base ^ Input'
members.name: baseval

members.text: Float : Supplies the exponent value for the function 'Input ^ Base'.
members.name: expval

members.text: Float : Allows setting the output to a specific constant value using the 'Constant' function.
members.name: constval

members.text: Menu : Determines whether the input values are measured in degrees, radians, etc for functions that require an angle input e.g. sine, cosine, etc.
members.name: angunit

members.text: Toggle : When enabled, output values that would otherwise be invalid will be replaced with the value of the 'Error Value' parameter. For example, when using the log function, the output will be replaced whenever the input value is less than zero.
members.name: replace

members.text: Float : The output value to use when an input error is detected e.g. log(-1).
members.name: errval

functionTOP.short: The Function TOP can perform mathematical operations like sin, cos, or exp on the color values of the input image.
functionTOP.long:
The Function TOP can perform mathematical operations like sin, cos, or exp on the color values of the input image. Different functions can be performed on each color channel. Some functions will take an additional value from the Base, Exponent or Constant Value parameters, and some functions take an additional input value from the second input image.
    
For some functions, you can use the 'Replace Errors' parameter to insert a new value for values that would otherwise be undefined e.g. log(-1)
    
===== Supported functions: =====
* ''Input'' - Pass along the input value unchanged
* ''Constant'' - Replace the input with the value of the 'Constant' parameter.
* ''Square Root'' - Find the square root of the input value i.e. sqrt(x).
* ''Absolute Value'' - Get the absolute value of the input i.e. abs(x).
* ''Sign'' - Returns -1 if the input value is below 0, 0 if it equals 0, and 1 if it's greater than zero.
* ''Cosine'' - Returns the cosine of the input. <sup>1</sup>
* ''Sine'' - Returns the sine of the input. <sup>1</sup>
* ''Tangent'' - Returns the tangent of the input. <sup>1</sup>
* ''Arccosine'' - Returns the arccosine of the input i.e. acos(x). <sup>1</sup>
* ''Arcsine'' - Returns the sine of the input i.e. asin(x). <sup>1</sup>
* ''Arctan (Input1)'' - Returns the arctangent of the input i.e. atan(x). <sup>1</sup>
* ''Arctan (Input1 / Input2)'' - Returns the arctangent of input1 over input2 i.e. atan(x,y). <sup>1</sup>
* ''Hyperbolic Cosine'' - Returns the hyperbolic cosine of the input i.e. cosh(x). <sup>1</sup>
* ''Hyperbolic Sine'' - Returns the sine of the input i.e. sinh(x). <sup>1</sup>
* ''Hyperbolic Tangent'' - Returns the tangent of the input i.e. tanh(x). <sup>1</sup>
* ''Log Base 10'' - Returns the base 10 logarithm of the input i.e. log10(x).
* ''Log Base 2'' - Returns the base 2 logarithm of the input i.e. log2(x).
* ''Log Base N'' - Returns the base N logarithm of the input, where N is set by the 'Base Value' parameter.
* ''Natural Log'' - Returns the natural log of the input i.e. ln(x).
* ''Exponent'' - Returns e to the power of the input i.e. e^x.
* ''Exponent 2'' - Returns 2 to the power of the input i.e. 2^x.
* ''Exponent 10'' - Returns 10 to the power of the input i.e. 10^x.
* ''Base Power'' - Returns the 'Base Value' parameter to the power of x. <sup>2</sup>
* ''Input1 ^ Exponent'' - Returns the input value to the power of the exponent parameter. <sup>2</sup>
* ''Input1 ^ Input2'' - Returns the value of input 1 to the power of input 2. <sup>2</sup>
* ''dB to Power'' - Converts decibels to power.
* ''Power to dB'' - Converts power to decibels. The result will be an error if the value is less than or equal to zero.
* ''dB to Amplitude'' - Converts decibels to amplitude.
* ''Amplitude to dB'' - Converts amplitude to decibels. The result will be an error if the value is less than or equal to zero.

<sup>1</sup> The unit of the input for this function is determined by the 'Angle Units' parameter e.g. degrees, radians, etc.

<sup>2</sup> Using a negative exponent i.e. pow(x, -2) will produce an error value since negative exponents are undefined according to the GLSL specifications.

glslmultiTOP.label: glslmultiTOP

members.text: Menu : Pick what version of GLSL to compile the shader with.
members.name: glslversion

members.text: Menu : Choose what type of shader you are writing, vertex/pixel shader, or a compute shader.
members.name: mode

members.text: DAT :
members.name: predat

members.text: DAT : Points to the [[DAT]] holding the Vertex Shader. Drag & Drop a DAT here, or manually enter the path to the DAT.
members.name: vertexdat

members.text: DAT : Points to the [[DAT]] holding the Pixel Shader. Drag & Drop a DAT here, or manually enter the path to the DAT.
members.name: pixeldat

members.text: DAT : Points to the [[DAT]] holding the [[Compute Shader]]. Drag & Drop a DAT here, or manually enter the path to the DAT.
members.name: computedat

members.text: Pulse : When this button is pressed the node will try to pre-fill all it's uniform parameter with uniforms that are declare in the shader. Note that the shader compiler will likely not expose uniforms that are unused.
members.name: loaduniformnames

members.text: Toggle : Automatically set the dispatch size based on the compute shader's local size and the output texture resolution. Ensures at least one thread per pixel will execute.
members.name: autodispatchsize

members.text: Int : The dispatch size to use when executing a compute shader.
members.name: dispatchsize

members.text: Menu : Controls how the output textures will be accessed. If the textures will be read from (such as using previous frame's values), then the access should be changed to Read-Write instead of Write Only.
members.name: outputaccess

members.text: Menu : Specify what type of texture to create. When creating  a 3D texture the TOP will render once for every slice of the output. Refer to [[Write a GLSL TOP#3D Textures and 2D Texture Arrays | 3D Textures and 2D Texture Arrays]] for more info.
members.name: type

members.text: Menu : Set the depth of the 3D texture from the '''Input''' or the '''Custom Depth''' parameter.
members.name: depth

members.text: Int : Manually set the depth of the 3D texture, otherwise it will use the depth of the input.
members.name: customdepth

members.text: Toggle :
members.name: clearoutputs

members.text: RGBA :
members.name: clearvalue

members.text: Menu : Determines how the node's input(s) are passed into the shader for use when creating a 3D Texture. By default all of the inputs are passed to each slice. When using the '''N inputs per Slice''' mode, the first N inputs are passed to the first slice, the next N inputs are passed the second slice, and so on. When it runs out of inputs it loops back to the first input. N is selected by the parameter '''N Value'''.
members.name: inputmapping

members.text: Int : Determines how many inputs are passed to the shader per slice when using the '''N inputs per Slice''' mode for '''Input Mapping'''. If for example this is set to 2, then the first 2 inputs will be passed to the first slice, the next 2 inputs will be passed the second slice, and so on. It will loop back to the start of the inputs if it runs out before it reaches the last slice.
members.name: nval

members.text: Menu : Controls what is returned from your texture sampling functions when the U and V texture coordinates (called S and T in the shader) are outside [0-1] range.
members.name: inputextenduv

members.text: Menu : Controls what is returned from your texture sampling functions when the W texture coordinate (called W in the shader) are outside [0-1] range. Only useful for [[3D Texture]].
members.name: inputextendw

members.text: Int : Any shader you write can output to more than one RGBA buffer at a time. Turn up this value to have more color buffers allocated for you, and refer to [Write_a_GLSL_TOP#Outputting_to_Multiple_Color_Buffers Write a GLSL TOP] for more information on using this feature.
members.name: numcolorbufs

members.text: Str : The uniform name, as declared in the shader
members.name: uniname0

members.text: XYZ : The value(s) to give the uniform.

members.text: Str : The name of the uniform. You can send up to 4 channels into the GLSL shader in a single uniform. The number of channels is determined by the float/vec2/vec3/vec4 menu to the right of the name. For a CHOP with a single channel declare your uniform as a float, for one with two channels declare your uniform as a vec2, etc. The data is interleaved in the uniform. I.e the .x component is the 1st channel, .y is the 2nd channel, etc.

members.name: matvalue0

members.name: acname0

members.text: Menu : Specifies how the atomic counters receive their initial value, either through a single default value or a CHOP.

members.text: Int : Specifies a single value that all atomic counters in this binding will be initialized to.
members.name: acsingleval0

members.text: CHOP : A reference to the CHOP that will determine the initial values of the atomic counters in this binding. The CHOP will be spanned in track order, so the values from the first track will be read in order first, then the next track (if there is one) and so on. If there are more initial values to fill than there are values in the CHOP then they will all be set to 0. Atomic counters will be initialized from low to high offsets.
members.name: acchopval0

glslmultiTOP.long:
The GLSL Multi TOP renders a GLSL shader into a TOP image. Its parameters and functionality are identical to the [[GLSL TOP]], except it allows for more than 3 inputs.
Refer to the [[GLSL TOP]] help page for more information.
glslmultiTOP.short: The GLSL Multi TOP renders a GLSL shader into a TOP image.

glslTOP.label: glslTOP

members.text: Menu : Pick what version of GLSL to compile the shader with.
members.name: glslversion

members.text: Menu : Choose what type of shader you are writing, vertex/pixel shader, or a compute shader.
members.name: mode

members.text: DAT : Use this DAT to place preprocessor directives at the start of your shader, such as #extension. This is required since these need to be the first lines in the shader, and TouchDesigner will be adding code to the start of your shader to declare uniforms/functions which would appear before #extension directives located in the main shader.
members.name: predat

members.text: DAT : Points to the [[DAT]] holding the Vertex Shader. Drag & Drop a DAT here, or manually enter the path to the DAT.
members.name: vertexdat

members.text: DAT : Points to the [[DAT]] holding the Pixel Shader. Drag & Drop a DAT here, or manually enter the path to the DAT.
members.name: pixeldat

members.text: DAT : Points to the [[DAT]] holding the [[Compute Shader]]. Drag & Drop a DAT here, or manually enter the path to the DAT.
members.name: computedat

members.text: Pulse : When this button is pressed the node will try to pre-fill all it's uniform parameter with uniforms that are declare in the shader. Note that the shader compiler will likely not expose uniforms that are unused.
members.name: loaduniformnames

members.text: Toggle : Automatically set the dispatch size based on the compute shader's local size and the output texture resolution. Ensures at least one thread per pixel will execute.
members.name: autodispatchsize

members.text: Int : The dispatch size to use when executing a compute shader.
members.name: dispatchsize

members.text: Menu : Controls how the output textures will be accessed. If the textures will be read from (such as using previous frame's values), then the access should be changed to Read-Write instead of Write Only.
members.name: outputaccess

members.text: Menu : Specify what type of texture to create. When creating  a 3D texture the TOP will render once for every slice of the output. Refer to [[Write a GLSL TOP#3D Textures and 2D Texture Arrays | 3D Textures and 2D Texture Arrays]] for more info.
members.name: type

members.text: Menu : Set the depth of the 3D texture from the '''Input''' or the '''Custom Depth''' parameter.
members.name: depth

members.text: Int : Manually set the depth of the 3D texture, otherwise it will use the depth of the input.
members.name: customdepth

members.text: Toggle : When using a Compute Shader, this controls if the output texture should be cleared at the start of each cook. Otherwise the data from the previous cook will stay in the texture, and pixels can be left as-is in the Compute Shader.
members.name: clearoutputs

members.text: RGBA : The color value to clear all pixels to at the start of the cook.
members.name: clearvalue

members.text: Menu : Determines how the node's input(s) are passed into the shader for use when creating a 3D Texture. By default all of the inputs are passed to each slice. When using the '''N inputs per Slice''' mode, the first N inputs are passed to the first slice, the next N inputs are passed the second slice, and so on. When it runs out of inputs it loops back to the first input. N is selected by the parameter '''N Value'''.
members.name: inputmapping

members.text: Int : Determines how many inputs are passed to the shader per slice when using the '''N inputs per Slice''' mode for '''Input Mapping'''. If for example this is set to 2, then the first 2 inputs will be passed to the first slice, the next 2 inputs will be passed the second slice, and so on. It will loop back to the start of the inputs if it runs out before it reaches the last slice.
members.name: nval

members.text: Menu : Controls what is returned from your texture sampling functions when the U and V texture coordinates (called S and T in the shader) are outside [0-1] range.
members.name: inputextenduv

members.text: Menu : Controls what is returned from your texture sampling functions when the W texture coordinate (called W in the shader) are outside [0-1] range. Only useful for [[3D Texture]].
members.name: inputextendw

members.text: Int : Any shader you write can output to more than one RGBA buffer at a time. Turn up this value to have more color buffers allocated for you, and refer to [Write_a_GLSL_TOP#Outputting_to_Multiple_Color_Buffers Write a GLSL TOP] for more information on using this feature.
members.name: numcolorbufs

members.text: Str : The uniform name, as declared in the shader
members.name: uniname0

members.text: XYZ : The value(s) to give the uniform.
members.name: value0

members.text: Str : The name of the uniform. You can send up to 4 channels into the GLSL shader in a single uniform. The number of channels is determined by the float/vec2/vec3/vec4 menu to the right of the name. For a CHOP with a single channel declare your uniform as a float, for one with two channels declare your uniform as a vec2, etc. The data is interleaved in the uniform. I.e the .x component is the 1st channel, .y is the 2nd channel, etc.
members.name: chopuniname0

members.text: Menu : The data type of the uniform in the shader.
members.name: chopunitype0

members.text: CHOP : The channels from this CHOP will be sent to the GLSL shader.
members.name: chop0

members.text: Menu : The type of the uniform.
members.name: choparraytype0

members.text: Str : The name of the matrix uniform.
members.name: matuniname0

members.text: OP : The value to assign the matrix. For valid ways to specify this, see the [[Matrix Parameters]] article.
members.name: matvalue0

members.text: Str : The name of the uniform.
members.name: acname0

members.text: Menu : Specifies how the atomic counters receive their initial value, either through a single default value or a CHOP.
members.name: acinitval0

members.text: Int : Specifies a single value that all atomic counters in this binding will be initialized to.
members.name: acsingleval0

members.text: CHOP : A reference to the CHOP that will determine the initial values of the atomic counters in this binding. The CHOP will be spanned in track order, so the values from the first track will be read in order first, then the next track (if there is one) and so on. If there are more initial values to fill than there are values in the CHOP then they will all be set to 0. Atomic counters will be initialized from low to high offsets.
members.name: acchopval0

members.text: Str : The constant name, as declared in the shader.
members.name: constname0

members.text: Int : The value to give the constant.
members.name: constvalue0

glslTOP.long: The GLSL TOP renders a GLSL [[shader]] into a TOP image. Use the Info DAT to check for compile errors in your shaders. The GLSL TOP can act as a pixel shader, or the more general and complex [[Compute Shader]]. Caveat: Compute Shaders need GLSL 4.30 or later. Refer to the [[Write a GLSL TOP]] article for more info on using this TOP. The GLSL TOP has one docked compute shader as well as a normal GLSL shader. Change he Mode to Compute Shader. it will use the glsl1_compute DAT. See the [[:Category:GLSL|GLSL Category]] for more information, and [[Compute Shader]].
glslTOP.short: The GLSL TOP renders a GLSL [[shader]] into a TOP image.

hsvadjustTOP.label: hsvadjustTOP

members.text: RGB : The start color is the hue that the HSV adjustment is centered around. When adjusting a small hue range, this is the color that will be altered. In the example image above, the Start Color color is cyan with a hue value of 180.
members.name: startcolor

members.text: Float : This is the range of color from the Start Color that will be adjusted. A range of 1 will only adjust the colors that are the same as the start color. A range of 360 will adjust all colors. For example, a range of 20 and a Start Color of 180 will adjust colors in the hue range of 170-190.
members.name: huerange

members.text: Float : This controls the falloff from the Hue Range. Higher values give more falloff, blending the hue range softly from hues that are adjusted to hues that are not.
members.name: huefalloff

members.text: Float : This is the range of saturation to adjust from the saturation of the Start Color. The Range is from 0 to 1.
members.name: saturationrange

members.text: Float : This controls the falloff from the Saturation Range selected.
members.name: saturationfalloff

members.text: Float : This is the range of value to adjust from the value of the Start Color. The Range is from 0 to 1.
members.name: valuerange

members.text: Float : This controls the falloff from the Value Range selected.
members.name: valuefalloff

members.text: Float : Adjust the hues selected above. The Hue Offset ranges from 0 to 360. For example, if the initial pixel color is 180 then a Hue Offset of 100 will change the hue  of 180 (cyan) to be a hue of 280 (violet).
members.name: hueoffset

members.text: Float : Adjusts the saturations selected above. This will multiply the saturation values specified by Saturation Range and Falloff parameters above. Setting this to 0 will reduce the selected saturation to 0, setting it to 1 will maintain the current saturation values, and setting it to 2 will make the selected saturation twice as saturated.
members.name: saturationmult

members.text: Float : Adjusts the values selected above. This will multiply the values specified by Value Range and Falloff parameters above.
members.name: valuemult

hsvadjustTOP.long: The HSV Adjust TOP adjust color values using hue, saturation, and value controls. If you change the Hue Offset, Saturation Multiplier and Value Multiplier without changing any of the other parameters then you will modify the color of all pixels in the image. The other parameters are used to narrow the range of pixels you want to modify based on their hue, saturation and value. For example if you leave the Hue Range untouched but reduce the saturation range, you will cause the TOP to modify only pixels who fall into the new saturation range. The range is the Start Color's saturation + the Range + the Falloff, in this example.
hsvadjustTOP.short: The HSV Adjust TOP adjust color values using hue, saturation, and value controls.

importselectTOP.label: importselectTOP

members.text: comp : Specify the import parent (eg. USD/FBX COMP) to search for the asset. When no COMP is specified it will by default search in the first import parent in its path.
members.name: parent

members.text: minimenu dynamicmenu : Specifies a path to the texture image.
members.name: texture

members.text: pulse : Reloads the asset from the import parent.
members.name: reload

importselectTOP.short: The Import Select TOP loads the texture map images such as Color Map, Normal Map, Metallic Map and so forth that are defined in [[FBX COMP]] or [[USD COMP]].
importselectTOP.long: The Import Select TOP loads the texture map images such as Color Map, Normal Map, Metallic Map and so forth that are defined in [[FBX COMP]] or [[USD COMP]]. The image binaries can be encoded within the importing file (e.g. .usdz format) or specified as an external asset with an valid path. See also: [[FBX COMP]], [[USD COMP]]

inTOP.label: inTOP

members.text: Str : Creates a pop-up label when the cursor rolls over this Component input.
members.name: label

inTOP.long: The In TOP is used to create a TOP input in a Component. Component inputs are positioned alphanumerically on the left side of the Component.
inTOP.short: The In TOP is used to create a TOP input in a Component.

insideTOP.label: insideTOP

members.text: Menu : The selected input will become the fixed layer and the other input will be the overlay. This does not change the order of the composite (Input1 + Input2), only which layer is considered fixed and which layer is adjustable by the parameters on the Transform page. The resolution and aspect ratio of the Fixed Layer is used as the composite's final resolution and aspect ratio unless manually on the [[#Parameters - Common Page|Common Page]].
members.name: size

members.text: Menu : Determines how the Overlay layer (Overlay layer is the input that is NOT the Fixed Layer) fills the composite.
members.name: prefit

members.text: Menu : Specify the horizontal alignment of the Overlay.
members.name: justifyh

members.text: Menu : Specify the vertical alignment of the Overlay.
members.name: justifyv

members.text: Menu : Sets the extend (or repeat) conditions of the Overlay layer. This parameter determines what happens at the edges of the Overlay layer.
members.name: extend

members.text: Float : Rotates the Overlay layer. Increasing values rotate clockwise, decreasing values rotate counter-clockwise.
members.name: r

members.text: XY : Translates the Overlay layer in x and y.
members.name: t

members.text: Menu : Sets the units used in the Translate parameter.
members.name: tunit

members.text: XY : Scales the Overlay layer in x and y.
members.name: s

members.text: XY : Allows you to define the point about which the Overlay layer scales and rotates. Altering the pivot point produces different results depending on the Transform Order.
members.name: p

members.text: Menu : Sets the units used in the Pivot parameter.
members.name: punit

insideTOP.long: The Inside TOP places Input1 'inside' Input2. The alpha of Input2 is used to determine what parts of the Input1 image are visible.
insideTOP.short: The Inside TOP places Input1 'inside' Input2.

kinectazureselectTOP.label: kinectazureselectTOP

members.text: Toggle : Controls whether this TOP is retrieving image data from the device. The primary [[Kinect Azure TOP]] must also be active to receive data.
members.name: active

members.text: TOP : The name of the primary [[Kinect Azure TOP]] that is configuring the camera. The primary TOP controls which camera the select TOP receives data from, as well as all device configuration such as resolution, framerate, etc.
members.name: top

members.text: Menu : A list of available image types to capture from the device and display in this TOP. All image types have a second version that is mapped (aligned) to the image space of the other camera so that color and depth image data can be matched. The resolution of the image is controlled by the Color Resolution or Depth Mode parameters of the primary [[Kinect Azure TOP]].
members.name: image

members.text: Toggle : When enabled, the current image will be remapped to align with images from the other camera. For example, use this feature to create a color camera image that maps to the pixels of the depth camera. The current depth mode and color resolution will be used to do the remapping. Note: Remapping the point cloud image can create artifacts in the distribution of points due to gaps in the remapping algorithm.
members.name: remapimage

members.text: Toggle : When enabled, the image produced will be delayed so that it corresponds to the most recent data from the body tracking system.
members.name: bodyimage

members.text: Toggle : Flip the image in the horizontal axis.
members.name: mirrorimage

kinectazureselectTOP.hardware: An NVIDIA GEFORCE GTX 1070 or better graphics card is required to obtain efficient body tracking data from the camera, although a CPU-only mode can be enabled using the parameters.
kinectazureselectTOP.short: The Kinect Azure Select TOP can be used to capture additional images from a Microsoft Kinect Azure camera that is controlled by a [[Kinect Azure TOP]].
kinectazureselectTOP.long:
The Kinect Azure Select TOP can be used to capture additional images from a Microsoft Kinect Azure camera that is controlled by a [[Kinect Azure TOP]].

This TOP must be used along with a [[Kinect Azure TOP]].

kinectazureTOP.label: kinectazureTOP

members.text: Toggle : Enable or disable the camera. '''Note''' Disabling this TOP will also disable any other operators ([[Kinect Azure Select TOP]] or [[Kinect Azure CHOP]]) that rely on it.
members.name: active

members.text: StrMenu : The serial number of the connected Kinect Azure camera. The TOP will automatically fill the list with all available cameras. Note: Only one Kinect Azure TOP should be connected to a single camera.
members.name: sensor

members.text: Menu : The resolution of images captured by the color camera. Different resolutions may have different aspect ratios. Note: 4096 x 3072 is not supported at 30 FPS.
members.name: colorres

members.text: Menu : The depth mode controls which of the Kinect's two depth cameras (Wide or Narrow FOV) are used to produce the depth image and whether any 'binning' is used to process the data. In 'binned' modes, 2x2 blocks of pixels are combined to produce a filter, lower resolution image. Note: Body tracking is not supported when using the Passive IR depth mode.
members.name: depthmode

members.text: Menu : Controls the frame rate of both the color and depth cameras. Some higher camera resolutions are not supported when running at 30FPS. Lower framerates can produce brighter color images in low light conditions.
members.name: fps

members.text: Toggle : When enabled, body tracking calculations will be done on the CPU rather than on the graphics card. This method is much slower, but does not require a high-powered graphics card to function.
members.name: cpu

members.text: File : The file path to the onnx model that performs body tracking features. TouchDesigner includes the regular and lite models that are part of the Kinect Azure SDK.
members.name: modelpath

members.text: Menu : Determines how the body tracking model is processed. The default mode runs mostly on the GPU (supports Nvidia, AMD and Intel), but this can also be switched to a CPU mode when a compatible GPU is not available.
members.name: proccessingmode

members.text: Int : The device number of the GPU to use when there are multiple GPUs in the system. The ordering system may be dependent on the GPU manufacturer.
members.name: gpu

members.text: Menu : Used to indicate when the camera is mounted in a non-upright position. This can help improve body-tracking results.
members.name: orientation

members.text: Menu : A list of available image types to capture from the device and display in this TOP. All image types have a second version that is mapped (aligned) to the image space of the other camera so that color and depth image data can be matched. The resolution of the image is controlled by the Color Resolution or Depth Mode parameters depending on the type of image selected. Use a [[Kinect Azure Select TOP]] to access additional image types from the same camera.
members.name: image

members.text:
Toggle : When enabled, the current image will be remapped to align with images from the other camera. For example, use this feature to create a color camera image that maps to the pixels of the depth camera.
The current depth mode and color resolution will be used to do the remapping.
Note: Remapping the point cloud image can create artifacts in the distribution of points due to gaps in the remapping algorithm.
members.name: remapimage

members.text: Toggle : When enabled, the image produced will be delayed so that it corresponds to the most recent data in the body tracking system. The amount of delay may fluctuate based on the power of the processor doing the body tracking and the complexity of the scene. A [[Kinect Azure Select TOP]] can be used at the same time to retrieve the real-time image stream.
members.name: bodyimage

members.text: Toggle : Flip the image in the horizontal axis.
members.name: mirrorimage

members.text:
Toggle : Enable to allow setting the exposure time manually. When disabled, the camera will automatically choose an exposure based on the light levels and frame rate.
Note: This feature may not work correctly due to issues in the current Kinect SDK.
members.name: manualexposure

members.text:
Int : Adjust the exposure time of the color image measured in microseconds. The time must be less than one frame.
Note: This feature may not work correctly due to issues in the current Kinect SDK.
members.name: exposure

members.text: Toggle : Enable to allow setting the camera white balance manually.
members.name: manualwhitebalance

members.text: Int : Select the temperature in degrees Kelvin used to set the white balance of the image. The value is rounded to the nearest 10 degrees.
members.name: whitebalance

members.text: Int : Used to adjust the brightness of the image from 0 to 255. 128 is the default.
members.name: brightness

members.text: Int : Conrtols the contrast of the color image.
members.name: contrast

members.text: Int : Controls the saturation of the color image.
members.name: saturation

members.text: Int : Adjusts the sharpness of the color image.
members.name: sharpness

members.text: Int : The gain of the color image.
members.name: gain

members.text: Toggle : Enables compensation for bright back lighting in a scene.
members.name: backlight

members.text: Menu : Select the frequency of the power supply for use in the cameras noise cancellation system.
members.name: powerfreq

members.text: Int : A delay in microseconds between when the depth and color images are captured. The delay must be less than one frame in length based on the current framerate.
members.name: depthdelay

members.text: Menu : When using more than one Kinect Azure camera, this setting can be used to determine which unit is the master and which are subordinates.
members.name: syncmode

members.text: Int : A delay in microseconds between when the master unit captures an image and when this device captures an image. (Only applicable for subordinate devices).
members.name: subdelay

members.text: Toggle : Enable or disable the camera. '''Note''' Disabling this TOP will also disable any other operators ([[Kinect Azure Select TOP]] or [[Kinect Azure CHOP]]) that rely on it.
members.name: active

members.text: StrMenu : The serial number of the connected Kinect Azure camera. The TOP will automatically fill the list with all available cameras. Note: Only one Kinect Azure TOP should be connected to a single camera.

In 'binned' modes, 2x2 blocks of pixels are combined to produce a filter, lower resolution image. Note: Body tracking is not supported when using the Passive IR depth mode.

All image types have a second version that is mapped (aligned) to the image space of the other camera so that color and depth image data can be matched. The resolution of the image is controlled by the Color Resolution or Depth Mode parameters depending on the type of image selected. Use a [[Kinect Azure Select TOP]] to access additional image types from the same camera.
members.name: image

members.text:
Toggle : When enabled, the current image will be remapped to align with images from the other camera. For example, use this feature to create a color camera image that maps to the pixels of the depth camera.
The current depth mode and color resolution will be used to do the remapping.
Note: Remapping the point cloud image can create artifacts in the distribution of points due to gaps in the remapping algorithm.

The amount of delay may fluctuate based on the power of the processor doing the body tracking and the complexity of the scene. A [[Kinect Azure Select TOP]] can be used at the same time to retrieve the real-time image stream.
members.name: bodyimage

Toggle : Enable to allow setting the exposure time manually. When disabled, the camera will automatically choose an exposure based on the light levels and frame rate.
Note: This feature may not work correctly due to issues in the current Kinect SDK.

members.text:
Int : Adjust the exposure time of the color image measured in microseconds. The time must be less than one frame.
Note: This feature may not work correctly due to issues in the current Kinect SDK.

kinectazureTOP.hardware: An NVIDIA GEFORCE GTX 1070 or better graphics card is required to obtain efficient body tracking data from the camera, although a CPU-only mode can be enabled using the parameters.
kinectazureTOP.short: The Kinect Azure TOP can be used to configure and capture data from a Microsoft Kinect Azure camera.
kinectazureTOP.long:
The Kinect Azure TOP can be used to configure and capture data from a Microsoft Kinect Azure camera. 
    
The TOP can be used to configure the settings of the camera (resolution, frame rate, synchronization, etc) as well to retrieve captured images from either its color or depth cameras. Image data from one camera can be remapped (aligned) to the other camera in order to match color and depth information. Only one Kinect Azure TOP can be connected to a single Kinect camera. To retrieve additional images from the same camera, use a [[Kinect Azure Select TOP]].
    
The Kinect Azure can also extract body tracking information and skeleton positions using the depth camera image. To access this data, use a [[Kinect Azure CHOP]] and set its Kinect TOP parameter to the primary [[Kinect Azure TOP]] that is connected to the device.

'''TIP:''' See Elburz' video on using KinectAzure's point clouds and a bunch of Azure general tips. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_PjAr2Yzao Kinect Azure Point Cloud in TouchDesigner Tutorial] on the Interactive and Immersive HQ.

See also [[Kinect Azure CHOP]], [[Kinect Azure Select TOP]], [[Palette:pointRender]], [[Palette:kinectCalibration]], [[Palette:kinectRecorder]], [[Palette:kinectPointcloud]].

kinectTOP.label: kinectTOP

members.text: Toggle : When 'On' data is captured from the Kinect sensor.
members.name: active

members.text: Menu : Choose between Kinect  v1 or Kinect v2 sensors.
members.name: hwversion

members.text: StrMenu : Selects which Kinect sensor to use. Only available when using Kinect v1.
members.name: sensor

members.text: Menu : Selects between the Color, Depth, Infrared, Player Index, or Color Point Cloud modes.
members.name: image

members.text: Menu : Only used for Kinect 1 devices. Selects the resolution of the camera capture.
members.name: camerares

members.text: Menu : Only used for Kinect 1 devices. Specify whether to track full skeleton or seated skeleton.
members.name: skeleton

members.text: Toggle : Only used for Kinect 1 devices. Enables near mode for the depth camera, which allows the depth camera to see objects as close as 40cm to the camera (instead of the default 80cm).
members.name: neardepthmode

members.text: Toggle : Flips the image in the y-axis.
members.name: mirrorimage

members.text: Toggle : Only used for Kinect 2 devices. Enabling this will remap images that are natively from the depth camera (Depth, Infrared, Player Index) to be in the space and resolution of the Color camera instead.
members.name: remap

members.text: Float : Only used for Kinect 1 devices. For depth pixels that are too close to resolve, this pixel value will be output instead.
members.name: tooclosevalue

members.text: Float : Only used for Kinect 1 devices. For depth pixels that are too far to resolve, this pixel value will be output instead.
members.name: toofarvalue

members.text: Float : For depth pixels whose depth can not be determined, output this value instead.
members.name: unknownvalue

members.text: Menu : When using the 'Color Point Cloud' some pixel's position can not be determined. This parameter controls what value to assign those pixels instead.
members.name: unknownpointvalue

kinectTOP.hardware: This TOP only supports the '''Kinect for Windows''' hardware and the '''Kinect 2''', ''not'' Kinect for Xbox hardware.
kinectTOP.long:
The Kinect TOP captures video from the [[Kinect]] depth camera or RGB color camera. 		

To use a Kinect 2 device you need to install the [https://www.microsoft.com/en-ca/download/details.aspx?id=44561 Kinect for Windows 2.0 SDK] or [https://www.microsoft.com/en-ca/download/details.aspx?id=44559 runtime].			
			
To use the original Kinect 1 device you will need to install the [http://www.microsoft.com/en-ca/download/details.aspx?id=40277 Kinect Runtime 1.8] for builds greater than 12000, or [http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=36997 Kinect Runtime 1.7] for builds below 12000.			

Kinect 2 supports color point clouds - getting the camera space positions of the color pixels, outputted as a 32-bit float RGB texture with XYZ in RGB. For use in making point clouds renders.			
			
See also [[Kinect CHOP]], [[Kinect]] and [[Kinect1]].
kinectTOP.short: The Kinect TOP captures video from the [[Kinect]] depth camera or RGB color camera.

layoutTOP.label: layoutTOP

members.text: TOP : Specify the path(s) to a TOP to include in the layout.
members.name: top

members.text: Toggle : When 'off', the resolution of the first wired input is used, or a custom resolution can be specified on the Common page. When 'on' and the output resolution is 'Use Input', the Layout TOP's resolution is the first input's resolution scaled up by number of columns horiontally, and the number of rows vertically. For example, if there are 4 input textures and the first one is 1280x720 and Align Left to Right is selected, then the grid size is 4x1 and so the final resolution will be 5120x720 (ie. (1280*4)x(720*1)). However whether off or on, each texture gets an allotted space of the same size. How the texture fits into that space is determined using the Fit parameter.

members.text: Menu : The menu attached to this parameter allows you to specify the order in which the changes to your inputs will take place. Changing the Transform order will change where things go much the same way as going a block and turning east gets you to a different place than turning east and then going a block.

layoutTOP.short: The Layout TOP positions multiple input TOPs into rows, columns, or grids.
layoutTOP.long:
The Layout TOP positions multiple input TOPs into rows, columns, or grids. It can either fit all the TOPs into a specific resolution (determined by the Common page) by scaling the inputs, or it can scale its own resolution to be larger to accomodate the native resolution of the inputs.
    
Each input image gets equal area of the output, and the Fit menu determines how each image fits into its designated area.

Multiple inputs can be wired into the Layout TOP, or the TOP parameter can contain paths to multiple TOPs. In the final layout, the TOPs specified in the TOP parameter will appear before the TOPs of the wired inputs if both are used.
